The petitioner filed O.P. No. 1502 of 1960 in the High Court of Kerala at Emakulam for a relief similar to that now sought in this petition.

anchor.surface_text: Every citizen whose fundamental right is infringed by the State has a fundamental right to approach this Court for enforcing his right. If by a final decision of a competent Court his title to property has been negatived, he ceases to have the fundamental right in respect of that property and, therefore, he can no longer enforce it.

arguments.claim: Petitioner has possessory title to the disputed wall under sale deed and is entitled to protection under Art. 19(1)(f).

anchor.surface_text: The Sale deed under which the petitioner has purchased the Eastern Palace from the Maharaja is filed along with the petition as Annexure A-2. Under the said sale deed, dated January 7, 1959, the Maharaja sold the Eastern Palace situate in survey Nos. 646 to 650, 2 acres and 57 cents, in extent, to the petitioner. The outer compound walls of the said Palace building were also expressly conveyed under the sale deed.

arguments.claim: Travancore Ancient Monuments Preservation Regulation 1 of 1112 M.E. ceased to be law, impliedly repealed by Central Acts (1904, 1951, 1958).

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether the Travancore Ancient Monuments Preservation Regulation Regulation 1 of 1112/M.E. ceased to be law in the State of Kerala and, therefore, the said notification issued thereunder had no legal force. It was contended that Regulation 1 of 1112 M.E. was impliedly repealed by the extension of the Central Act, i.e., the Ancient Monuments Preservation Act, 1904

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e a law in respect of ancient and historical monuments and records declared by or under law made by it to be of national importance, but the Central A

arguments.court_reasoning: No repeal as Central Acts require declaration of national importance, absent here; state act holds field per legislative lists.

arguments.claim: State Regulation continued in force; not repealed by Central Acts lacking national importance declaration.

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether the Travancore Ancient Monu- ments. Preservation Regulation  Regulation 1 of 1112/M.E.  ceased to be law in the State of Kerala... For the aforesaid reasons it must be held that notwithstanding the extension of the Central Act VII of 1904 to the Travancore area and the passing of Central Acts LXXI of 1951 and XXIV of 1958, the State Act continued to hold the field in respect of the monument in question.

arguments.claim: Parliament lacks competence over monuments not declared of national importance per Seventh Schedule Entries 67 List I, 12 List II.

anchor.surface_text: To appreciate this contention it would be convenient at the outset to notice the relevant legislative fields allotted to the Central and State Legislatures by the entries in the three Lists of the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution. Entry 67 of List 1  Union List  Ancient and historical monuments and records, and archaeological sites and remains, declared by or under law made by Parliament to be of national importance.

arguments.claim: Disputed wall is not an ancient monument but an archaeological site or remains, covered by Entry 40 List III; Central Act occupies field.
arguments.court_reasoning: Fort wall is historical monument (surviving structure), not site for exploration; distinction per Constitution lists and dictionary meanings; state proceeded as monument.

arguments.claim: Fort wall is a monument, not archaeological site; distinction clear per Constitution and dictionary.

anchor.surface_text: The entire record placed before us discloses that the State proceeded on the basis that the Fort wall was a monument... Monument is derived from monere, which means to remind, to warn. Monument means, among others, a structure surviving from a former period whereas archaeology is the scientific study of the life and culture of ancient peoples.

arguments.claim: State Government competent to declare Fort walls as protected monument under Regulation.

anchor.surface_text: Under that order the Government considered the Fort walls around the Sree Padmanabhaswamy Temple as of archaeological importance and that they should be preserved as a protected monument.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: that the Fort wall is a monument and the State Government was within its rights to issue the impugned numberification under s. 3 of the State Regulat

arguments.court_reasoning: Valid under state law for non-national monuments.

holdings.text: The petition is not barred by the principle of res judicata.

anchor.surface_text: Every citizen whose fundamental right is infringed by the State has a fundamental right to approach this Court for enforcing his right. If by a final decision of a competent Court his title to property has been negatived, he ceases to have the fundamental right in respect of that property and, therefore, he can no longer enforce it. In that context the doctrine of res judicata may be invoked. But where there is no such decision at all, there is no scope to call in its aid. We, therefore, reject this contention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior High Court dismissal was not on merits of fundamental right but for alternative civil remedy; Art. 32 allows direct approach unless title negatived by competent court.

holdings.text: The petitioner has possessory title in the wall and is entitled to be protected against interference with that right without the sanction of law under Art. 19(1)(f).

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, withholding, our final decision on this point, as we are satisfied that the petitioner has purchased the disputed wall from the Maharaja and is in physical possession thereof. Indeed, the fact that he is in possession has been admitted by the State in its counter-affidavit. It is stated therein that the petitioner has intermeddled with the wall. The petitioner has possessory title in the wall and is, therefore entitled to be protected against interference with that right without the sanction of law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sale deed prima facie conveys wall; possession admitted by State via intermeddling allegation.

holdings.text: The Travancore Ancient Monuments Preservation Regulation 1 of 1112 M.E. did not cease to be law; it continued to hold the field notwithstanding extension of Central Acts.

anchor.surface_text: For the aforesaid reasons it must be held that notwithstanding the extension of the Central Act VII of 1904 to the Travancore area and the passing of Central Acts LXXI of 1951 and XXIV of 1958, the State Act continued to hold the field in respect of the monument in question.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No implied repeal as Central Acts apply only to monuments declared of national importance, absent here; state law valid for others per extension conditions and no conflict.

holdings.text: The notification issued under the State Act was valid.

anchor.surface_text: It follows that the notification issued under the State Act was valid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from State Act remaining in force.

holdings.text: State Legislature has exclusive power over ancient monuments not declared of national importance per Entries 67 List I and 12 List II; Parliament cannot occupy field without declaration.

anchor.surface_text: To appreciate this contention it would be convenient at the outset to notice the relevant legislative fields allotted to the Central and State Legislatures by the entries in the three Lists of the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution. Entry 67 of List I (Union List): Ancient and historical monuments... declared... to be of national importance. Entry 12 of List II (State List): ... ancient and historical monuments... other than those declared... national importance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Constitutional distribution of legislative powers limits Parliament to declared national importance monuments; no such declaration for Fort wall.

holdings.text: The Fort wall is a monument, not an archaeological site or remains; State Government was within its rights to issue the impugned notification under s. 3 of the State Regulation.

anchor.surface_text: For the aforesaid reasons we hold that the Fort wall is a monument and the State Government was within its rights to issue the impugned notification under s. 3 of the State Regulation 1 of 1112 E.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinction between monument (surviving structure to remind) and archaeological site (for exploration/study) per dictionary, Constitution lists, and State treatment; not covered by concurrent power.

holdings.text: The Court is not deciding whether the wall in dispute is part of the Fort wall.

anchor.surface_text: We are not deciding in this case whether the wall in dispute is part of the Fort wall. Such and other objections may be raised under the provisions of the Act in the manner prescribed thereunder.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Insufficient evidence from affidavits; decision withheld as possessory right protected but notification valid.

holdings.text: It is not necessary to express opinion on whether Art. 363 bars the petition.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Unnecessary given resolution on other grounds.

anchor.surface_text: The extracts given in the companynter-affidavit filed by the State from the relevant Manuals and other books and documents show that the Fort wall was a historical monument and was treated as such, being the wall built around the famous Sree Padmanabhaswami Temple. It is number an archaeological site for exploration and study, but an existing structure surviving from a former period. For the aforesaid reasons we hold that the Fort wall is a monument and the State Government was within its rights to issue the impugned numberification under s. 3 of the State Regulation 1 of 1112 E.

outcome.relief_summary: Impugned notification held valid under the State Regulation; ownership dispute not decided; to be raised under the Act
directions: Such and other objections may be raised under the provisions of the Act in the manner prescribed thereunder

anchor.surface_text: Every citizen whose fundamental right is infringed by the State has a fundamental right to approach this Court for enforcing his right. If by a final decision of a competent Court his title to property has been negatived, he ceases to have the fundamental right in respect of that property and, therefore, he can no longer enforce it. In that context the doctrine of res judicata may be invoked. But where there is no such decision at all, there is no scope to call in its aid. We, therefore, reject this contention.

The extracts given in the companynter-affidavit filed by the State from the relevant Manuals and other books and documents show that the Fort wall was a historical monument and was treated as such, being the wall built around the famous Sree Padmanabhaswami Temple. It is number an archaeological site for exploration and study, but an existing structure surviving from a former period. For the aforesaid reasons we hold that the Fort wall is a monument and the State Government was within its rights to issue the impugned numberification under s. 3 of the State Regulation 1 of 1112 E.

We are, therefore, withholding, our final decision on this point, as we are satisfied that the petitioner has purchased the disputed wall from the Maharaja and is in physical possession thereof. Indeed, the fact that he is in possession has been admitted by the State in its counter-affidavit. It is stated therein that the petitioner has intermeddled with the wall. The petitioner has possessory title in the wall and is, therefore entitled to be protected against interference with that right without the sanction of law.

The extracts given in the companynter-affidavit filed by the State from the relevant Manuals and other books and documents show that the Fort wall was a historical monument and was treated as such, being the wall built around the famous Sree Padmanabhaswami Temple. anchor.surface_text: To appreciate this contention it would be convenient at the outset to notice the relevant legislative fields allotted to the Central and State Legislatures by the entries in the three Lists of the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution. Entry 67 of List I (Union List): Ancient and historical monuments... declared... to be of national importance. Entry 12 of List II (State List): ... ancient and historical monuments... other than those declared... national importance.

The extracts given in the companynter-affidavit filed by the State from the relevant Manuals and other books and documents show that the Fort wall was a historical monument and was treated as such, being the wall built around the famous Sree Padmanabhaswami Temple. It is number an archaeological site for exploration and study, but an existing structure surviving from a former period. For the aforesaid reasons we hold that the Fort wall is a monument and the State Government was within its rights to issue the impugned numberification under s. 3 of the State Regulation 1 of 1112 E.
